Infectious diseases are challenging to model, especially when incorporating climate effects. We present MR. NODE (Multiple predictoR Neural ODE), a neural network that models the dynamics of black Sigatoka infection using Neural Ordinary Differential Equations. Our method encodes external predictor factors into the latent space, in addition to the variable we infer, and can predict infection risk at any point in time. Empirically, we demonstrate on historical climate data that our method outperforms other models on time points up to one month in the future and unseen irregularities. We believe our method can be a useful tool to control the spread of black Sigatoka.

Introduction
Bananas are one of the most consumed fruits worldwide, with a global retail value between $20 and $25 billion in 2016 (BananaLink). However, banana production faces a predominant leaf-spot infectious disease called black Sigatoka (Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations, 2013). Caused by the fungal plant pathogen Mycosphaerella fijiensis, the disease leads to premature ripening and a 30-50% loss in yields (Queensland Government, 2021). Between 2007 and 2009, St. Vincent and the Grenadines faced a 90% decline in banana crop production due to black Sigatoka (Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations, 2013). Current protection measures include applying expensive fungicides regularly, which account for up to 40% of the cost of banana production (approximately $520 million per year globally) (Joint Genome Institute, U.S. Department of Energy, 2013). However, many local farmers in developing countries have no access to disease management facilities due to financial constraints (Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations, 2013). Predicting upcoming M. fijiensis infections on banana plants would allow farmers to take preventative measures and mitigate disease management costs.

Summary of Contributions
In this study, we predict the spread of black Sigatoka based on varying microclimatic conditions using a latent neural ODE approach.

* We propose Multiple predictoR Neural ODE, a type of ODE-Net that defines a latent generative function. Our method extends the architecture of latent Neural ODEs (Chen et al., 2018) to model multivariate time series with external factors.
* We demonstrate our method's effectiveness in learning the dynamics of generated black Sigatoka disease data based on a historical climate database.
* We trained and evaluated RNNs and LSTMs on our dataset as baseline models and demonstrate that our method outperforms them.

2. Relevant Work
Mathematical Models
In 1925, M'Kendrick invented the first mathematical algorithm for epidemics, consisting of a differential equation model that considers a fixed population with susceptible, infected, and recovered individuals (SIR). In 2016, Ochoa et al. suggested modeling black Sigatoka using the autoregressive integrated moving average (ARIMA) model. However, these "white box" models have few parameters and strong modeling assumptions, and are often too simplistic to capture the pattern of the disease precisely. Therefore, disease modeling would favor state-of-the-art neural network models, operated with fewer assumptions and more flexibility.

A Statistical Model
For a number of hypothetical cohorts of M. fijiensis spores, Bebber modeled the infection of black Sigatoka as a probabilistic survival process depending on three microclimatic condition variables: relative humidity (RH, in %), canopy temperature (T, in kelvin), and moisture storage on canopy (CM, in meters). A cohort of spores germinates and infects its host during wet periods and ceases the process during dry ones.
